conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, C, and D, and the task is to predict which container (E, F, G, or H) it will flow into after passing through baffles.
The solution involves analyzing the flow paths from the top containers (A, B, C, D) to the bottom containers (E, F, G, H) by tracing how liquid would move through the baffles.
The top containers A, B, C, and D have colored tabs (green, yellow, orange/yellow, and pink).
Colored rods/baffles are arranged in the middle area.
The bottom containers E, F, G, and H are marked with house-shaped outlines (pink, white, blue, and green).
Liquid drops from the green tab at point A.
Following gravity, the liquid from A first hits the leftmost green baffle.
The liquid flows down along the green baffle.
In the second and third images, the green liquid flow path continues down.
The green liquid path reaches the bottom at the rightmost container (green house shape).
Liquid from A flows to container H (rightmost green house).
Liquid drops from the yellow tab at point B.
The liquid from B encounters the yellow baffle.
The yellow flow path is shown in images 2 and 3.
The liquid from B follows down and slightly left.
The yellow path connects to the second container from the left (white house shape).
Liquid from B flows to container F (white house).
Liquid drops from the orange/yellow tab at point C.
The orange flow path is visible in images 2 and 3.
The orange liquid path moves through several baffles, including the white bar.
The orange liquid path eventually reaches the third container from the left (blue house shape).
Liquid from C flows to container G (blue house).
Liquid drops from the pink tab at point D.
